definitions.definition: To assume (a certain shape or visible structure).
examples: When you kids form a straight line I'll hand out the lollies.

definitions.definition: To give (a shape or visible structure) to a thing or person.
examples: Roll out the dough to form a thin sheet.
When icicles start to form on the eaves you know the roads will be icy.

definitions.definition: To put together or bring into being; assemble .
examples: The socialists did not have enough MPs to form a government.
Paul McCartney and John Lennon formed The Beatles in Liverpool in 1960.

definitions.definition: To create (a word) by inflection or derivation.
examples: By adding "-ness", you can form a noun from an adjective.

definitions.definition: To constitute , to compose , to make up .
examples: Teenagers form the bulk of extreme traffic offenders.

definitions.definition: To mould or model by instruction or discipline.
examples: Singing in a choir helps to form a child's sociality.

definitions.definition: To provide (a hare ) with a form.

To treat ( plates ) to prepare them for introduction into a storage battery , causing one plate to be composed more or less of spongy lead , and the other of lead peroxide . This was formerly done by repeated slow alternations of the charging current, but later the plates or grids were coated or filled, one with a paste of red lead and the other with litharge , introduced into the cell, and formed by a direct charging current.

main_definition: ( transitive ) To assume (a certain shape or visible structure).
secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To give (a shape or visible structure) to a thing or person.
To put together or bring into being; assemble .
( transitive , linguistics ) To create (a word) by inflection or derivation.
( transitive ) To constitute , to compose , to make up .
To mould or model by instruction or discipline.
To provide (a hare ) with a form.

( electrical , historical , transitive ) To treat ( plates ) to prepare them for introduction into a storage battery , causing one plate to be composed more or less of spongy lead , and the other of lead peroxide . This was formerly done by repeated slow alternations of the charging current, but later the plates or grids were coated or filled, one with a paste of red lead and the other with litharge , introduced into the cell, and formed by a direct charging current.
